text.title: part3_Van Canto's Stefan Schmidt on a capella metal, Wacken, Nightwish, piracy & more

list.item: What about in terms of style? Wacken is known for the variety, but your music is the most unusual and amongst the lightest at the festival. Is that a worry for you? What sort of reaction do you expect?

text.p: On every festival we played so far, people were first irritated, then a little bit amused and not later than the third song we played most of the people were enthusiastic about our songs. I hope this will be the way it turns out to be in Wacken.

list.item: What are your opinions on the other acts there? Are there any you want to see yourselves?

text.p: Iron Maiden of course, Nightwish are there and I’m also looking forward to the Avantasia show.

list.item: Have any of you ever been to Wacken before as a fan or fans?

text.p: Of course. I have been there 1998, 1999, 2002 and 2005.

list.item: Do you expect Wacken to open up new opertunities for you? Can we expect van Canto at, say, festivals in the US, UK or Japan?

text.p: Hmm – we hope so. We also have a great fan base in Brazil and try to get over there in the summer to do some shows.

list.item: How long is your slot at Wacken?
Will we see more new material than anything, or will you perform a mix?

text.p: This depends on how long our slot is, but I think the focus will be on the second album then.
text.head: On the future of metal

list.item: Do you expect a capella metal to become a more common genre?

text.p: I don’t know. I think it would be great if other bands tried out so we can share our experience and do not have to find out everything on our own, haha.

list.item: Do you expect other bands to be influenced and encouraged by your success?

text.p: I hope so. When we get mails from musicians or metalbands influenced by our style of songwriting our by the courage for doing something new we feel really great. I only started playing music because I was inspired by other bands as a teenager, it would be great if we could inspire other musicians, too.

list.item: Do you think the industry should be more accepting of fresh or unusual ideas?

text.p: I think the term “the industry” is too general for that kind of question. I think that today the chances to get heard are better than 10 years ago. Everybody can produce an “ok-sounding” album and put up a video in youtube. And if it’s done well and the idea sticks out, the industry will contact the band, which is their job, actually.

list.item: One subject that's been in the news a lot recently is bands complaining they feel exploited and/or by their record labels. Have you found this yourself?
